David Scherer
Andreas Emmertsen | board_of_directors = Michael Svarer
Jens Bjerg Sørensen
Peter Engberg Jensen
Nick Melgaard
Michael Jensen
Kristina Risom Jespersen
Kasper Vinther Olesen
Jens Riis Andersenhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/executive-board/ | type = Non-profit organisation | location = [[Aarhus University|University of Aarhus]], [[Aarhus]], [[Denmark]] | website = [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org aarhus-symposium.org] }} '''Aarhus Symposium''' is an annual leadership conference taking place at the [[Aarhus University|University of Aarhus]], [[Denmark]], on the first Friday in November. The aim of the event is to connect leaders of today with leaders of tomorrow. To do so, a wide range of key decision-makers are invited to share their experiences and engage in discussions with students from various universities. Hereby, the symposium allows students to relate their academic insights to the broader business society.http://studerende.au.dk/nyheder-og-arrangementer/nyhedsarkiv/nyhed/artikel/danske-topledere-ruster-au-studerende-til-barsk-virkelighed/ Aarhus Symposium was founded in 2011 and has since expanded its concept to also involve [[Aarhus Symposium#Aarhus Symposium Focus|Aarhus Symposium Focus]]http://www.netvaerksportalen.dk/artikler/studerende-og-topledere-moedes-i-faglig-debat-aarhus-symposium and [[Aarhus Symposium#Aarhus Symposium Challenge|Aarhus Symposium Challenge]].http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/97854/artikel.html Aarhus Symposium is a non-profit organisation, and all symposia are organised by voluntary students together with a pro-bono board of directors.http://jyllands-posten.dk/aarhus/erhverv/ECE7183981/Leder-event-udsolgt-p%C3%A5-90-sekunder/http://aarhus-symposium.org/become-a-partner/ == History == Four students at [[Aarhus University]] established Aarhus Symposium in 2011: David Scherer, Jens Riis Andersen, Kasper Vinther Olesen, and Andreas Emmertsen. They gathered support from other students to organise the very first Aarhus Symposium with the objective of building a bridge between students, i.e. the future leaders, and leaders in today’s businesses and society.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/12/3184822/artikel.htmlhttp://stiften.dk/aarhus/Erhvervslivets-tunge-drenge-yder-studiehjaelp/artikel/92572 The first annual Aarhus Symposium welcomed renowned speakers from the business society such as Carsten Bjerg (then CEO of [[Grundfos]]), Lars Rohde (then CEO of [[Arbejdsmarkedets Tillægspension|ATP]]), and Maria Rønn (CEO of [[DR (broadcaster)|Danmarks Radio]]).http://aarhus-symposium.org/past-symposia/growth-in-distressed-economies/ Throughout the years, the programme has extended to include prominent speakers such as [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark|His Royal Highness The Crown Prince of Denmark]],http://kongehuset.dk/menu/nyheder/abning-af-aarhus-symposium-2014 Lars Rebien Sørensen (president and CEO of [[Novo Nordisk]]),http://jyllands-posten.dk/aarhus/ECE8162162/Studerende-har-hyret-verdens-bedste-chef/ and the [[Denmark|Danish]] [[Prime minister|Prime Minister]] [[Lars Løkke Rasmussen]].https://jyskebank.tv/nutidens-og-fremtidens-ledere-modes-til-aarhus Aarhus Symposium has grown through the years as a result of wide support from students, speakers, partners, and others. In 2012, the Organising Committee introduced Battle of the Economists; an event to take place on Monday in the week of Aarhus Symposium. It provided a national focus to the overall theme of Aarhus Symposium.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/63904/artikel.html The event was renamed Aarhus Symposium Focus in 2016 to broaden the possibilities for topics that exceed economic issues.https://issuu.com/aarhussymposium/docs/booklet2016_final_rgb In 2013, Aarhus Symposium Challenge was established to strengthen the connection between students and the leaders of today. Aarhus Symposium Challenge is an essay competition in which selected speakers put forth a challenge for students to solve. Through their essay, students obtain a seat at both Aarhus Symposium and Aarhus Symposium Focus, and they potentially qualify for [[Aarhus Symposium#Leaders' Forum|Leaders’ Forum]]. Since its initiation in 2013, an increasing number of students have participated in Aarhus Symposium Challenge, making it the primary sign-up for Aarhus Symposium and Aarhus Symposium Focus.http://aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-challenge/ == Aarhus Symposium == [[File:ASClimate.jpg|thumb|left|Climate Debate at Aarhus Symposium 2015 between (from left) Andreas Roepstorff, Connie Hedegaard, and Simon Giles moderated by Poul Erik Skammelsen.]] Aarhus Symposium takes place on the first Friday in November. Here, business executives and key decision-makers are invited to share their experiences and insights regarding a specific theme. They do so with different perspectives that reflect the tracks, i.e. subtopics, of the event. {{Clear}} === Past symposia === [[File:ASCrown.jpg|thumb|right|His Royal Highness The Crown Prince of Denmark’s opening speech at Aarhus Symposium 2014.]] {| class="wikitable collapsible" |- ! Christiansen]], CEO, [[The Lego Group]] * Afshan Khan, Regional Director, Europe & Central Asia, [[UNICEF]] * Ulrik Juul Christensen, Executive Chairman, Area9 Group * Rodin Genoff, Founder & Managing Director, Rodin Genoff and Associates * Søren Skou, CEO, [[Maersk Group]] * Jakob Askou Bøss, Senior VP, Corporate Strategy and Stakeholder Relations, [[Ørsted (company)|Ørsted]] * Christian Erfurt, CEO and Co-Founder, Be My Eyes * Michael Bruun, Partner and Managing Director, [[Goldman Sachs]] * Inge Berneke, Partner, [[Egon Zehnder]] * Lars Jannick Johansen, Founder & Managing Partner, The Social Capital Fond * Lene Skole, CEO, Lundbeckfonden |720 |} == Aarhus Symposium Focus == ''Formerly known as Battle of the Economists'' Aarhus Symposium Focus is an annual conference which takes place on Monday in the week of Aarhus Symposium. The event provides a national focus as the topic strives to reflect one of Denmark’s most critical challenges.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/opinion/artikel/1/334143/thomas_bernt_loekke-retraete_er_tredobbelt_lussing_til_virksomhederne.html [[File:ASFocus.jpg|thumb|right|Participants at Battle of the Economists 2015]] {| class="wikitable collapsible" |- ! Christiansen, CEO, [[The Lego Group]]: ''How a company can enjoy the advantages of collaborating with others wile protecting its core values'' * Afshan Khan, Regional Director Europe & Central Asia, [[UNICEF]]: ''One area in which every child does not have equal opportunities and one way to address this issue'' * Ulrik Juul Christensen, Founder and Executive Chairman, Area9 Group: ''How to achieve a specific competence that will be important on the future labour market'' |} === Leaders' Forum === [[File:ASForum.jpg|thumb|left|Leaders’ Forum session with Connie Hedegaard at Aarhus Symposium 2015.]] Leaders’ Forum is an exclusive and intimate session where selected students discuss their essay contribution with the leader that put forth the respective challenge. Only the best essay contributions under each challenge topic qualifies for this informal session.http://aarhus-symposium.org/challenge-faq/ Throughout the years, Leaders’ Forum has attracted much attention from the media inasmuch as it is unique in a Danish context and provides both the attending students and the top leaders the opportunity to learn from each other.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/97871/artikel.htmlhttp://www.business.dk/digital/jimmy-maymann-det-nytter-ikke-at-ville-holde-fremskridtet-tilbage {{Clear}} === The Aarhus Symposium Award === [[File:ASAward.jpg|thumb|right|Oskar Harmsen, winner of the Aarhus Symposium Award 2015, rewarded on stage at Aarhus Symposium 2015.]] The most extraordinary essay contribution in Aarhus Symposium Challenge will be rewarded the Aarhus Symposium Award on stage at the very end of Aarhus Symposium. Prior winners of the Aarhus Symposium Award are: *2013: Bastian Stemann Lauhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/AarhusSymposiumChallenge2013_WinnerPortrait.pdf *2014: Moma Vujisichttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2014/12/02/meet-the-winner-of-the-aarhus-symposium-award-2014/ *2015: Oskar Harmsenhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2015/12/18/meet-the-winner-of-the-aarhus-symposium-award-2015/ *2016: Luke McGintyhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2017/03/26/interview-luke-mcginty-winner-aarhus-symposium-award-2016/ *2017: Bastian Emil Jørgensenhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2017/11/03/bastian-emil-jorgensen-winner-of-the-aarhus-symposium-award-2017/ *2018: Soraya Redondo Mezmizi {{Clear}} == Other events == Besides facilitating Aarhus Symposium and Aarhus Symposium Focus, Aarhus Symposium also hosts a variety of other events that takes places at Aarhus University. Most notable are Aarhus Symposium Theme Announcement and Aarhus Symposium Challenge Launch; both of which are closely linked to the three key elements of Aarhus Symposium.http://aarhus-symposium.org/news/http://omnibus.au.dk/en/archive/show/artikel/morgendagens-leder-er-det-dig/ == Organising Committee == The Organising Committee of Aarhus Symposium consists of approximately 35 voluntary students,http://aarhus-symposium.org/organisers/ who have the responsibility for planning, funding, promoting, and executing all events.http://bss.au.dk/om-aarhus-bss/nyheder/vis/artikel/hvordan-saetter-man-store-erhvervsledere-i-staevne/ The Organising Committee is divided into smaller groups with specific focus areas:http://aarhus-symposium.org/organisers/the-groups-of-aarhus-symposium/ *Steering Committee *Programme Group *Business Relations Group *Marketing Group *Essentials Group *University Alliances *IT Group *Finance Group == External links == *Website: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org aarhus-symposium.org] *Aarhus Symposium: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium] *Aarhus Symposium Focus: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-focus aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-focus] *Aarhus Symposium Challenge: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-challenge/ aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-challenge/] == References == {{reflist|2}} [[Category:Events in Denmark]] [[Category:Organized events]] [[Category:Aarhus University]] [[Category:Student events]] [[Category:Conferences]] [[Category:Academic conferences]] [[Category:Organizations based in Aarhus]] [[Category:Student organizations in Denmark]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Denmark]] [[Category:Business conferences]] [[Category:Autumn events in Denmark]]

{{multiple issues| {{notability|Events|date=January 2013}} {{orphan|date=January 2013}} {{primary sources|date=January 2013}} }} '''Boutique Week''' is a bi-annual shopping event in New York, Boston, Los Angeles, Chicago, and Miami. Boutique Week was launched in October 2010 in New York, Boston, and Los Angeles with over 40 [[boutiques]] participating in each city.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boutiqueweek.net |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100919143430/http://www.boutiqueweek.net/ |archivedate=2010-09-19 |df= }}</ref> Each of the participating boutiques offers their merchandise at a discount of at least 25% off during the selected week.
==support== Boutique Week is supported by local government in these cities as an effort to stimulate the economy and raise awareness for small local businesses.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boutiqueweek.net/index.php?view%3Dpage%26pageId%3D3 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101023054400/http://boutiqueweek.net/index.php?view=page&pageId=3 |archivedate=2010-10-23 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://boldfacers.com/index.cfm?page%3Dhappenings |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708081449/http://boldfacers.com/index.cfm?page=happenings |archivedate=2011-07-08 |df= }}</ref>
Boutique Week also raises money for [[Nancy Lublin]]'s non-profit organisation [[Dress For Success (organization)|Dress for Success]], supplying women with [[interview suit]]s and resources they need for success in today's workforce.
==Founders== Boutique Week was founded in July 2010 by Polina Raygorodskaya and Olga Vidisheva.
Polina Raygorodskaya<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polinafashion.com|title=NYC Fashion PR, Marketing, Fashion Public Relations|website=www.polinafashion.com}}</ref> is the founder and president of Polina Fashion LLC. Formerly a top [[runway model]], Raygorodskaya earned a [[BS degree]] in [[Business Administration]] at [[Babson College]]. Her entrepreneurial endeavors have been recognized by [[Fox Business Channel]] and [[LegalZoom]]. In 2007, [[Business Week]] named her as one of the "Best 25 Entrepreneurs Under 25".<ref>http://www.businessweek.com/smallbiz/content/oct2007/sb20071019_394343_page_2.htm</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legalzoom.com/business-management/success-stories/hottest-young-entrepreneurs|title=The Hottest Young Entrepreneurs of 2008|date=1 December 2009|publisher=}}</ref>
Olga Vidisheva is currently pursuing a [[Masters degree]] in Business Administration at [[Harvard Business School]]. Most recently, she worked for [[Chanel]] in their 'Fashion' and 'Fragrance and Beauté' marketing divisions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nypost.com/pagesixmag/issues/20100914/Harvard+Goes+High+Fashion |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918031704/http://www.nypost.com/pagesixmag/issues/20100914/Harvard%2BGoes%2BHigh%2BFashion |archivedate=2010-09-18 |df= }}</ref>
==Notes== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using >ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100919143430/http://www.boutiqueweek.net/ Boutique Week website] * [http://www.dressforsuccess.org/ Dress for Success website]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{main|Great Famine (Ireland)}} [[File:Irish potato famine Bridget O'Donnel.jpg|thumb|An 1849 depiction of Bridget O'Donnell and her two children during the famine.]] The '''Chronology of the Great Famine''' ({{lang-ga|'''An Gorta Mór'''}}<ref>The term has appeared in the titles of numerous books on the event, as demonstrated by [http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=%22Gorta+Mo%CC%81r%22&=Search&qt=results_page this search on WorldCat]</ref> or ''An Drochshaol'', litt: ''The Bad Life'') documents a period of Irish history between 1845 and 1852<ref>Kinealy (1995), xvi–ii.</ref> during which time the population of Ireland was reduced by 20 to 25 percent.<ref>Christine Kinealy, This Great Calamity, Gill & Macmillan (1994), {{ISBN|0-7171-4011-3}}, 357.</ref> The [[proximate cause]] was [[famine]] resulting from a potato disease commonly known as [[late blight]].<ref>Cormac Ó Gráda, ''Ireland's Great Famine: Interdisciplinary Perspectives'', Dublin: University College Dublin Press, 2006, p. 7. {{ISBN|1-904558-57-7}}</ref> Although blight ravaged potato crops throughout Europe during the 1840s, the impact and human cost in Ireland{{spaced ndash}}where a third of the population was entirely dependent on the potato for food{{spaced ndash}}was exacerbated by a host of political, social and economic factors which remain the subject of historical debate.
An important and controversial point of debate, that is notable amongst Irish people, was that Irish food supplies were sufficient until it was taken away by the British the feed the British, and the landlords kept economic benefits to themselves. Some commentators and writers controversially compared this explanation to "genocide".
<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith, ''The Great Hunger'', Harmondsworth: Penguin, 1991, p. 19. {{ISBN|978-0-14-014515-1}}</ref><ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity'', Gill & Macmillan, 1994, pp. xvi–ii, 2–3. {{ISBN|0-7171-4011-3}}</ref>
== Chronology ==
===1845===
====August==== At the beginning of August, [[Robert Peel|Sir Robert Peel]], the British Prime Minister, received news of a potato disease in the South of England. This was the first recorded evidence that the 'blight' which had ravaged the potato crop in North America in 1843-1844 had crossed the Atlantic. Cecil Woodham-Smith would write that a failure in England would be serious, but for Ireland, it would be a disaster.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 39</ref>
====September==== Following earlier reports of incidences of the blight in England, on 13 September 1845 <ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity'', Gill & Macmillan, 1994, {{ISBN|0-7171-4011-3}} pg.32 put the date at the 16th</ref> potato blight was first reported in Ireland. The crops at Dublin were suddenly perishing, it was reported in the ''Gardeners' Chronicle'', asking "where will Ireland be in the event of a universal potato rot?" The British Government were nevertheless optimistic through the next few weeks.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 39–40</ref>
====October==== [[File:Skibbereen by James Mahony, 1847.JPG|thumb|[[Skibbereen]] 1847 by [[Cork (city)|Cork]] artist [[James Mahony]] (1810–1879), commissioned by the ''[[Illustrated London News]]'']] *As soon as digging of potato crops began, devastating reports started coming in. Sir Robert Peel found the accounts 'very alarming' and writing to Sir James Graham, the Home Secretary on 13 October reminded him that there was always a tendency in Irish news to exaggerate.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'' pg.41</ref> Constabulary Reports from the 15 reported great failures, Sir James Graham, the Home Secretary wrote that the truth about the potato crop, until digging was completed, could not be fully ascertained.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'' pg.42</ref> *The Prime Minister [[Robert Peel]] was prompted to act,<ref>''The Course of Irish History'' (1994) edited by T.W.Moody and F.X.Martin. Page 268. Mercier Press. {{ISBN|1-85635-108-4}}.</ref> and on 15 October he decided to summon an emergency meeting of his Cabinet for 31 October. The remedy he decided was to repeal the [[Corn Laws]].<ref name="cws-p50">Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'' pg.50</ref> Peel then decided to set up a Scientific Commission to go to Ireland and investigate the potato blight and report on conditions.<ref>James S. Donnelly, Jr, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing 2005, UK, {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}} pg.44</ref><ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'' pg.44</ref> *The emergency Cabinet meeting met on 31 October till 1 November. The first day consisted of reading reports and memoranda from Ireland on the potato failure. Peel proposed that a relief commission be established in Ireland, and a sum of money be advanced to the Lord -Lieutenant. Differences arose when Peel pointed out that these measures required an advance of public money. The purchase of food for destitute districts would open the question of [[Corn Laws]]. Was it possible, it was asked, to vote public money for the sustenance of a people on account of "actual or apprehended scarcity" and still maintain restrictions on the free import of grain; Peel declared it was not.<ref name="cws-p51">Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'' pg.51</ref> On this issue then the Cabinet split, the overwhelming majority voting against Peel.<ref>Cormac Ó Gráda, Ireland's Great Famine: Interdisciplinary Perspectives, Dublin: University College Dublin Press, 2006, p. 7. {{ISBN|1-904558-57-7}} pg.15</ref> Unable to reach a decision, the Cabinet adjourned till 6 November.<ref name="cws-p51"/>
The principle of the Corn Laws had been to keep the price of home-grown grain up. Duties on imported grain assured English farmers a minimum and profitable price. The burden of a higher price for bread was carried by the labouring classes, in particular factory workers and operatives. It was claimed that if the Corn Laws were repealed all those connected with the land would be ruined and the established social organisation of the country destroyed.<ref name="cws-p50"/>
According to Cecil Woodham-Smith, the rising wrath of Tories and landlords ensured "all interest in Ireland was submerged." She writes that the Tory Mayor of Liverpool refused to call a meeting for the relief of Irish distress. She continues that the [[Mansion House Committee]] in Dublin was accused of 'deluding the public with a false alarm', and the blight itself 'was represented as the invention of agitators on the other side of the water'. The entanglement of the Irish famine with the repeal of the Corn Laws, she says, was a key misfortune for Ireland. The potato failure was eclipsed by the domestic issue of Corn Law repeal. The Irish famine, she writes, "slipped into the background."<ref name="cws-p50"/>
====November====
*On 9–10 November<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 54</ref> Peel ordered the secret purchase of £100,000 worth of [[Maize|Indian corn]] and meal from America for distribution in Ireland.<ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52'', Dublin: Gill & Macmillan, 1994. {{ISBN|0-7171-1832-0}} pg.38, 46</ref><ref>James S. Donnelly, Jr, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing 2005, UK, {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}} pg.49</ref> *On 15 November the Scientific Commissioners reported that half the potato crop had been destroyed.<ref name="cws-p51"/> *On 19 November the Mansion House Committee in Dublin claimed to have "ascertained beyond the shadow of doubt that considerably more than one-third of the entire potato crop...has been already destroyed."<ref>James S. Donnelly, Jr, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing 2005, UK, {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}} pg.43</ref> *On 20 November the Relief Commission first met.<ref>Christine Kinealy, This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52, Dublin: Gill & Macmillan, 1994. {{ISBN|0-7171-1832-0}} pg. 41</ref><ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 57</ref> *Unable to persuade his Cabinet to repeal the Corn Laws, on 5 December Peel tendered his resignation <ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52'', Dublin: Gill & Macmillan, 1994. {{ISBN|0-7171-1832-0}} pg.37</ref> to Queen Victoria but was reinstated days later when [[John Russell, 1st Earl Russell|Lord John Russell]] was unable to form a government.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 52</ref>
===1846=== The first deaths from hunger took place in early 1846.<ref>Thomas Keneally (1999) ''The Great Shame''. London: Vintage: 110</ref> In March Peel set up a programme of public works in Ireland but was forced to resign as Prime Minister on 29 June.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 78–86</ref> The new Whig administration under [[John Russell, 1st Earl Russell|Lord Russell]], influenced by their [[laissez-faire]] belief that the market would provide the food needed<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 408–11</ref> then halted government food and relief works, leaving many hundreds of thousands of people without any work, money or food.<ref name="david2002">David Ross (2002) ''Ireland: History of a Nation'': 224, 311</ref> Grain continued to be exported from the country.<ref name="david2002"/> Private initiatives such as The Central Relief Committee of the Society of Friends (Quakers) attempted to fill the gap caused by the end of government relief and eventually the government reinstated the relief works, although bureaucracy slowed the release of food supplies.<ref name="david2002"/> The blight almost totally destroyed the 1846 crop and the Famine worsened considerably.<ref name="david2002"/> By December a third of a million destitute people were employed in public works.<ref>David Ross (2002) ''Ireland: History of a Nation'': 311</ref>
===1847=== [[File:Emigrants Leave Ireland by Henry Doyle 1868.jpg|thumb|''Emigrants Leave Ireland'', engraving by Henry Doyle (1827–1892), from Mary Frances Cusack's Illustrated History of Ireland, 1868]] There were average crop yields in the 1847 harvest, but due to lack of seed potatoes to plant, the crop was low.<ref>Líam Kennedy, Paul S. Ell, E. M. Crawford & L. A. Clarkson, Mapping The Great Irish Famine, Four Courts Press, 1999, {{ISBN|1-85182-353-0}} pg.69</ref> Crowds began to throng the public works during the last months of 1846 and the start of 1847, which promoted exactly the social conditions for the spread of 'famine fever.'<ref>James S. Donnelly, JR, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing (UK 2005 RP), {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}}, pg.173</ref> In late January and February, legislation called the Temporary Relief Act went through the British parliament; it became popularly known as the Soup Kitchen Act and occasionally as Burgoyne's Act.<ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52'', Dublin: Gill & Macmillan, 1994. {{ISBN|0-7171-1832-0}} pg 136</ref> This system of relief was designed to deliver cheap food directly and gratuitously to the destitute masses. This system of relief would be terminated in September.<ref>James S. Donnelly, JR, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing (UK 2005 RP), {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}}, pg. 81–85</ref> The government also announced an additional change in the system of relief. After August 1847, the permanent Poor Law was to be extended and was to become responsible for providing relief and as a result, all relief would be financed by the local Poor Law rates.<ref>Christine Kinealy, ''This Great Calamity: The Irish Famine 1845–52'', Dublin: Gill & Macmillan, 1994. {{ISBN|0-7171-1832-0}} pg 137</ref> This put impossible loads on local poor rates, particularly in the rural west and south.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 174–187</ref> With the mass emigration of the famine era, the horrors of the '[[coffin ships]]' and 1847 have ever since been associated in the popular mind, according to James S. Donnelly.<ref>James S. Donnelly, JR, ''The Great Irish Potato Famine'', Sutton Publishing (UK 2005 RP), {{ISBN|0-7509-2928-6}}, pg.179</ref>
In December 1847 The [[Crime and Outrage Bill (Ireland) 1847]] was enacted due to growing Irish nationalist agitation that was causing the British government concern about a possible [[Young Irelander Rebellion of 1848|violent rebellion]] against British rule in Ireland.<ref>Woodham-Smith, Cecil [[The Great Hunger]] Ireland1845 1849 Harper and Row New york pages 326-327</ref>
The bill gave the [[Lord Lieutenant of Ireland]] the power to organise the island into districts and bring police forces into them at the districts' expense. It limited who could own guns, and required all of the men in the district between the ages of 16 and 60 to assist in apprehending suspected murderers when landlords were killed, or else be guilty of a misdemeanour themselves.
===1848=== The blight returned in 1848 and outbreaks of cholera were reported.<ref name="david20022002"/> Evictions became common among the Irish who could not keep up with the demands of their British landlords. Famine victims on outdoor relief peaked in July at almost 840,000 people.<ref name="david20022002"/> On 29 July [[Young Irelander Rebellion of 1848|an uprising against the government]] was led by [[William Smith O'Brien]]. After a skirmish at "[[Famine Warhouse 1848|Widow McCormack's house]]" in the village of [[Ballingarry, South Tipperary|Ballingarry]], [[County Tipperary]] the leaders of the rebellion fled to America or were sentenced to transportation.<ref name="david20022002"/><ref>Robert Kee (2000) ''The Green Flag: A History of Irish Nationalism'': 270-89</ref>
===1849=== The potato crop failed again in 1849 and famine was accompanied by cholera outbreaks.<ref name="david20022002"/> This deadly cholera epidemic killed one of Ireland's greatest poets: [[James Clarence Mangan]].<ref name="david20022002"/>
===1850=== The Famine ended.<ref name="david20022002">David Ross (2002) ''Ireland: History of a Nation'': 313</ref>
===1851=== By 1851 census figures showed that the population of Ireland had fallen to 6,575,000 – a drop of 1,600,000 in ten years.<ref name="david20022002"/> Cormac Ó Gráda and Joel Mokyr have described the 1851 census as a famous but flawed source. They contend that the combination of institutional and individuals figures gives "an incomplete and biased count" of fatalities during the famine.<ref name="cormac2006">Cormac Ó Gráda, Ireland’s Great Famine: Interdisciplinary Perspectives, University College Dublin Press, 2006, {{ISBN|1-904558-57-7}} pg. 3</ref> The famine left in its wake up to a million dead and another million emigrated.<ref>David Ross (2002) ''Ireland: History of a Nation'': 226</ref> The famine caused a sense of lasting bitterness by the Irish towards the British government, whom many blamed — then and now — for the starvation of so many people.<ref>Cecil Woodham-Smith (1962) ''The Great Hunger: Ireland 1845-9'': 412–13</ref> The fall-out of the famine continued for decades afterwards.
==See also== {{Commons category|Potato famine of Ireland}} * [[Irish Famine (1740–41)]] * [[Irish Famine (1879)]] * [[Legacy of the Great Irish Famine]] (continuation of this article) * [[Highland Potato Famine]] (1846–57) (agrarian crisis in Scotland at the same time) * [[European Potato Failure]] (the wider agrarian crisis in Europe at the same time) * [[List of natural disasters in the British Isles]] * "[[The Fields of Athenry]]," a popular song about the famine * [[List of famines]] * [[Holodomor]], a 1930s famine in [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukraine]], the causes of which are also the subject of debate

{{short description|The history and future of the universe according to Big Bang cosmology}} {{see also|Timeline of the formation of the Universe}} {{pp-move-indef|small=yes}} [[File:CMB Timeline300 no WMAP.jpg|thumb|upright=2|Diagram of evolution of the (observable part) of the universe from the Big Bang (left) to the present]] {{Physical cosmology}} {{Nature timeline}} The '''chronology of the universe''' describes the history and [[future of the universe]] according to [[Big Bang]] cosmology. The earliest stages of the universe's existence are estimated as taking place 13.8 [[billion years]] ago, with an [[confidence level|uncertainty]] of around 21 million years at the 68% confidence level. The [[Planck (spacecraft)#2015 data release|Planck Collaboration]] in 2015 published the estimate of 13.799 ± 0.021 billion years ago (68% confidence interval). See Table 4 on page 31 of pdf. {{Cite journal |author=Planck Collaboration |date=2015 |title=Planck 2015 results. XIII. Cosmological parameters |journal=[[Astronomy & Astrophysics]] |volume=594 |issue=13 |pages=A13 |arxiv=1502.01589 |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201525830 |bibcode=2016A&A...594A..13P }} ==Outline== For the purposes of this summary, it is convenient to divide the chronology of the universe since it [[Cosmogony|originated]], into five parts. It is generally considered meaningless or unclear whether [[time]] existed before this chronology: :'''1. The [[#Very early universe|very early universe]]''' – the first [[picosecond]] (10−12) of cosmic time. It includes the [[Planck epoch]], during which currently understood [[laws of physics]] may not apply; the emergence in stages of the four known [[fundamental interaction]]s or [[force]]s – first [[gravity]], and later the [[strong interaction|strong]], [[weak interaction|weak]] and [[electromagnetic interaction|electromagnetic]] interactions; and the [[metric expansion of space|expansion of space]] and [[supercooling]] of the still immensely hot universe due to [[cosmic inflation]], which is believed to have been triggered by the separation of the [[Strong interaction|strong]] and [[electroweak interaction]]. :Tiny ripples in the universe at this stage are believed to be the basis of large-scale structures that formed much later. Different stages of the very early universe are understood to different extents. The earlier parts are beyond the grasp of practical experiments in [[particle physics]] but can be explored through other means. :'''2. The [[#Early universe|early universe]]''', lasting around 377,000 years. Initially, various kinds of [[subatomic particle]]s are formed in stages. These particles include almost equal amounts of [[matter]] and [[antimatter]], so most of it quickly annihilates, leaving a small excess of matter in the universe. :At about one second, [[Neutrino decoupling|neutrinos decouple]]; these neutrinos form the [[cosmic neutrino background]]. If [[primordial black hole]]s exist, they are also formed at about one second of cosmic time. [[Composite particle|Composite]] [[subatomic particle]]s emerge – including [[proton]]s and [[neutron]]s – and from about 3 minutes, conditions are suitable for [[nucleosynthesis]]: around 25% of the protons and all the neutrons [[nuclear fusion|fuse]] [[big bang nucleosynthesis|into heavier elements]], mainly [[helium-4]]. :By 20 minutes, the universe is no longer hot enough for fusion, but far too hot for neutral [[atom]]s to exist or [[photon]]s to travel far. It is therefore an [[Opacity (optics)|opaque]] [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]]. At around 47,000 years,Ryden, Barbara, "Introduction to Cosmology", 2006, eqn. 6.33, 6.41 as the universe cools, its behavior begins to be dominated by [[matter]] rather than radiation. :At about 377,000 years {{citation needed|date=November 2018}}, the universe finally becomes cool enough for neutral [[atom]]s to form ("[[Recombination (cosmology)|recombination]]"), and as a result it also became [[Transparency and translucency|transparent]] for the first time. The newly formed atoms – mainly [[hydrogen]] and [[helium]] with traces of [[lithium]] – quickly reach their lowest energy state ([[ground state]]) by releasing photons ("[[decoupling (cosmology)|photon decoupling]]"), and these photons can still be detected today as the [[cosmic microwave background]] (CMB). This is currently the oldest observation we have of the universe. :'''3. Dark Ages and large-scale [[structure formation|structure emergence]]''', from 377,000 years until about 1 billion years. After [[recombination (cosmology)|recombination]] and [[decoupling (cosmology)|decoupling]], the universe was transparent but the clouds of [[hydrogen]] only collapsed very slowly to form [[star]]s and [[galaxy|galaxies]], so there were no new sources of light. The only photons (electromagnetic radiation, or "light") in the universe were those released during decoupling (visible today as the [[cosmic microwave background]]) and [[hydrogen line|21 cm radio emissions]] occasionally emitted by hydrogen atoms. The decoupled photons would have filled the universe with a brilliant pale orange glow at first, gradually [[redshift]]ing to non-visible [[wavelength]]s after about 3 million years, leaving it without visible light. This period is known as the [[Dark Ages (cosmology)|Dark Ages]]. :Between about 10 and 17 million years the universe's average temperature was suitable for liquid water (273 – 373K) and there has been speculation whether rocky planets or indeed life could have arisen briefly, since statistically a tiny part of the universe could have had different conditions from the rest, and gained warmth from the universe as a whole. :At some point around 400 to 700 million years, the earliest generations of [[stellar evolution|stars]] and [[galaxy formation and evolution|galaxies form]], and early large structures gradually emerge, drawn to the foam-like [[dark matter]] [[filament (cosmology)|filaments]] which have already begun to draw together throughout the universe. [[Population III star|The earliest generations of stars]] have not yet been observed astronomically. They may have been huge and [[metallicity|non-metallic]] with very short lifetimes compared to [[Main Sequence|most stars we see today]], so they commonly finish burning their [[hydrogen]] fuel and explode as [[supernova]]e after mere millions of years. Other theories suggest that they may have included small stars, some perhaps still burning today. In either case, these early generations of supernovae created most of the everyday [[chemical element|elements]] we see around us today, and seeded the universe with them. :[[Galaxy cluster]]s and [[supercluster]]s emerge over time. At some point, high energy photons from the earliest stars, [[dwarf galaxy|dwarf galaxies]] and perhaps [[quasar]]s led to a period of [[reionization]]. The universe gradually transitioned into the universe we see around us today, and the Dark Ages only fully came to an end at about 1 billion years. :'''4. The universe as it appears today'''. From 1 billion years, and for about 12.8 billions of years, the universe has looked much as it does today. It will continue to appear very similar for many billions of years into the future. The [[thin disk]] of [[Milky Way|our galaxy]] began to form at about 5 billion years (8.8 bn years ago),{{cite journal |last1=del Peloso |first1=E. F. |last2=da Silva |first2=L. |last3=Porto de Mello |first3=G. F. |last4=Arany-Prado |first4=L. I. |title=The age of the Galactic thin disk from Th/Eunucleocosmochronology. III. Extended sample |journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics |date=2005 |volume=440 |issue=3 |pages=1153–1159 |doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20053307 |bibcode= 2005A&A...440.1153D | arxiv=astro-ph/0506458}} and the [[formation and evolution of the Solar System|solar system]] formed at about 9.2 billion years (4.6 bn years ago), with the earliest traces of [[timeline of the evolutionary history of life|life]] on Earth emerging by about 10.3 billion years (3.5 bn years ago). :From about 9.8 billion years of cosmic time, the slowing expansion of space gradually begins to accelerate under the influence of [[dark energy]], which may be a [[scalar field]] throughout our universe. The present-day universe is understood quite well, but beyond about 100 billion years of cosmic time (about 86 billion years in the future), uncertainties in current knowledge mean that we are less sure which path our universe will take. :'''5. [[Fate of the universe|The far future]]'''. At some time the [[Stelliferous Era]] will end as stars are no longer being born, and the expansion of the universe will mean that the observable universe becomes limited to local galaxies. There are various scenarios for the far future and [[ultimate fate of the universe]]. More exact knowledge of our current universe will allow these to be better understood. ==A more detailed summary== {{further|Timeline of the formation of the Universe|Timeline of natural history|Geologic time scale|Timeline of the evolutionary history of life|Timeline of the far future}} {{further|Graphical timeline of the universe|Graphical timeline of the Big Bang|Graphical timeline from Big Bang to Heat Death|Graphical timeline of the Stelliferous Era}} Earliest stages of chronology shown below (before neutrino decoupling) are an active area of research and based on ideas which are still speculative and subject to modification as scientific knowledge improves. "Time" column is based on extrapolation of observed [[metric expansion of space]] back in the past. For the earliest stages of chronology this extrapolation may be invalid. To give one example, [[eternal inflation]] theories propose that inflation lasts forever throughout most of the universe, making the notion of "N seconds since Big Bang" ill-defined. The radiation temperature refers to the [[cosmic background radiation]] and is given by 2.725·(1+''z''), where ''z'' is the [[redshift]]. {| class="wikitable" |---- ! Epoch ! Time !
